He knows a lot about the fishes and food, and made the wait goes very pleasent.After the auction we walked around the area, and bought some fresh seafood for our breakfast we had at a nice place, where I met the chef Hirobumi Morita!During the tour Tsubasa mentioned about the workshop and if it is as good as his guidance through the market, it will be great!! I'll definitely try to do when I'm back in Tokyo!つばざさん, ありがとうございましたSandra

Highlight of my week in Tokyo!. This was my second visit to Tsukiji Fish Market, and it was so worth the return trip!Big thanks to Tsubasa-san and his colleagues for showing us around the Inner Market, explaining how the market works, showing us so many fish and seafoods I'd never seen before. Great fun to learn about buying fish, what to look for when buying to make sushi vs cooking fish. Lots of details on how to fillet the various fish/shellfish, how to prepare it for sushi. Lots of laughs and just a lovely way to spend a morning!Highly recommend it. I had hemmed and hawed about the price, but it was worth every penny.

Great chance to make your own sushi. The first half of the workshop is the market tour. I had heard that all the tourism has ruined the market, but frankly, that's just wrong. Even though we go at the end of the market hours and there are lots of tourists with cameras, it's an incredible experience. So many fishes you never knew existed, huge slabs of tuna, beautiful uni, it goes on for row after row into the dimly lit distance. Tsubasa was knowledgeable and friendly, showed us lots of great stands, and then took us to buy fish. We learned about feeling the gills (deep red and slimy is good!) the color of the skin, how good squid reacts when you touch it. And then we were off to watch the filleting. After learning the differences in preparing sea bream, sea bass, flounder, blood clam, squid, and scallops (and tuna, but we had just bought a piece of a tuna, not the whole fish!), it was time to make the sushi. Some people had the discipline to make a whole plate of sushi before starting; I couldn't wait. Make a piece, eat it. Pleasant staff, a fun group of people on the tour - it was a lot of fun.

Incredible sushi making class and Tsukiji tour. This was by far the highlight of our trip to Tokyo . The class was fun, our classmates interesting and most important our teachers excellent.. Cant wait to do it again

Super sushi class!. I had a wonderful sushi class today with Hirobumi (the chef) and Tsubasa, our super friendly and helpful guide. Very good English too. The morning session was full so Hiro accomodated us by opening a class just for us at 2:30 in the afternoon. The class was hands on and more than I expected. I really learned a lot and am excited to go home and practice. Thanks Hiro and Tsubasa for the great, funfilled day we had today! Made our trip to Tokyo so memorable.

Really fun tour!. We had a really eventful and fun morning, experiencing the tuna auction followed by the Tsukiji market guided tour.Thanks to our guide who reminded us to get to the market earlier than scheduled, if not, we wouldn't have been able to get in. In fact, we were already on the late tour when we got in at 3am!Watching the tuna auction on TV documentary was already pretty incredible, so having to see it live right in front of your own eyes was truly out-of-this-world!After the tuna auction, we met up with one of the sushi masters, Morita-san (who's a true Tsukiji insider and knows everyone and everything about the market!), and toured the inner and outer market. The inner market is open to general public after 9am but we managed to get in 2 hours earlier thanks to Morita-san.It will be a very meaningful tour for all food lovers, and for people who'd rather be spending their money on experiences.

Great for tourist or local expats. This is a great tour for tourists, local expats and/or sushi lovers. The tour leaders were very knowledgeable about the market and fish. We really enjoyed helping them choose fish for our lunch and then helping to prepare it. A wonderful experience I have already recommended to friends.

Excellent!. We had a really informative and fun tour of the inner and outer fish markets, followed by an excellent sushi workshop, using the ultra-fresh fish from the market. Our guides were very knowledgable and able to explain many fascinating aspects about the fish market (how to select best fish quality etc), and also how to correctly make sushi. Great organization and really useful and friendly too - Highly recommend!

Fish Market Tour and Sushi Class. Fun morning! We first toured the amazing inner market and learned from Morita-san how to pick the best seafood for sushi. We also shopped in the outer market then watched chef Noji-san clean and prepare the fish. We practiced how to cut the fish and made the sushi, then ate!
Master Breakfast. Wonderful experience, learn much and had lots of fun! Looking forward to join next time! And the Lovely Master breakfast!

Tsukiji Sushi Workshop. Great workshop with knowledgeable English speaking guides and Japanese speaking chef. Before the workshop, visiting the fish market to select the fish was great fun and an experience. The guides joined us to the fish market and workshop.The chef was patiently. First showing how to clean the fish and how to prepare the sushi in 7 steps.During the workshop we made 10 different sushi with the prepared fish. The end of the workshop is eating the sushi together.Good fun and a super experience you can take home to your own kitchen and share with family and friends. Good experience with teens, business or couples too.

Great discovery of the Kabuki world with professional and very friendly guide!. For our 1st day in Japan this tour was an excellent start for our 14 days discovery.Kazui is a very professional guide with excellent communication skills and on top very friendly. You feel the passion and the proud of her love for the Kabuki by the sharing of her knowledge in such a devoted way. The tea experience was also amazing with the typical Matcha tea and lovely sweets.Don't hesitate to subsribe for a tour with Kazui!

Wonderful Experience! Highly recommend this tour! Amazing guide!. Kazui's kabuki tour was absolutely wonderful. She was great to deal with on e-mail prior to the tour (before we event left for Japan) and recommended seats that fit our budget. She e-mailed us programs to read in advance, so we can read them at our leisure. We were a family of 3 (with an 11-year old) and the tour was tailored to all of us with historical facts about the kabuki itself, interactive experience for the 11-year old, and specially designed programs for the show we were about to see. The tour included lecture on kabuki, visit to a very interactive kabuki museum and some good tips on what to get (food, guides) or visit (paintings exhibition) while at the theater. In my opinion this is a must do attraction while in Tokyo not only because you will learn about Japanese theater and culture, but you will be learning it from extremely knowledgeable and simply amazing person. Thank you, Kazui for a great tour and sharing the magic of kabuki with us!

Very informative and really enjoyable. It helped to understand the atmosphere of the theater.. Kazui is a very enthusiastic person. You feel that she loves what she does. Kazui was of great helped even before we decided to take the tour. She answered all my questions promptly and when we finally met her she was very happy to go out of her way to help us to make the most of this wonderful experience. Kazui sent the summaries of the plays before we left England so we all read them before we went to the theater. Her talk helped us to understand Kabuki and everything that was going to happen in the theather, while seeing the performances.We bought 3A grade tickets and I regret I did not spend more money and got better seats. If you are tall these ones are a bit uncomfortable.Do not forget to hire the English subtitles devices as they are a must to follow the plays.My oldest daughter loves drama so she was very excited about going to this tour and seeing the plays but even my youngest, who is not so much into drama enjoyed the experience. I highly recomend this tour and Kabuki.

What a show!. Kabuki is a must see spectacle in Japan and Kazui managed to book us some of the best seats for the first performance of the season. The show was an experience that none of us will ever forget, and it would've been much harder to understand the performance without Kazui's help. Kazui explained the history of kabuki in great details over delicious matcha tea and japanese sweets at a nearby tea house before we headed over together to watch the matinee show. I would recommend her tour to everyone and look forward to seeing a new performance on our next trip to Japan. Thank you Kazui!

Performed first by a woman and now exclusively by men, a must-see while in Japan!. I have always wanted to visit Japan, and kabuki has long fascinated me. I was not disappointed when the opportunity finally presented itself to have both wishes fulfilled! Kazui was absolutely wonderful and immensely helpful every step of the way, I would not have had the same depth of appreciation if I had not participated in this tour. Before I had even left my own country, Kazui sent through seating plans, maps for where we would meet, and backstories each of the plays I would be seeing! I purchased a box seat ticket on the 2nd floor (I think the 1st floor box seats they deliver your food to you) which was well worth the additional price as I had one of the best views of the stage in the theater. Kazui also helped me purchase a bento box (delicious) and English subtitle guide beforehand. The pre-performance lecture was fantastic and she broke down everything from the actors lineage to the symbolism of each characters makeup. Make sure to leave plenty of time to purchase a taiyaki (fish-shaped cake filled with sweetened bean paste). Kazui swears the ones purchased at the Kabuki-za theater are the best in Tokyo and as someone who is now a converted fan of Japanese sweets and deserts I concur!! As for the kabuki plays - breathtaking. I intend to return to Japan within the next two years and I will most definitely do this tour again.

Unique Kabuki experience. If you are going to visit a Kabuki Theatre in Tokyo, I strongly recommend you to do this tour. Kazui is a lovely person. She will give you a nice overview of Kabuki with really helpful information for each performance. It definitely increase your understanding of Kabuki and experience during the performance.

Highlight of our trip to Tokyo!. This was a truly wonderful tour, and the highlight of our trip to Tokyo. Thank you, Kazui-San! While I've previously experienced kabuki and enjoyed it very much, I found that everything Kazui-San taught us really enriched the experience. After understanding more about both the history of kabuki and the techniques used both on and off stage, it was much easier to wholeheartedly engage in the action. I found the production fascinating (and unusual from a Western perspective) since every character in this act was sympathetic, and there was no "villain". As someone who is interested in Japanese history, I found the interplay between truth and fantasy very compelling, and this has changed the way I now think when I read history. Without Kazui-San's thorough explanations about kabuki conventions, I might have found these changes confusing, but certainly would not be able to identify with the real historical figures portrayed in this show so well as I do now. I was also very impressed with the way in which Kazui-San catered for a group with widely different knowledge bases (both about Japan in general and kabuki in particular). I attended the show with my father, who is very limited in his knowledge about Japanese culture. She ensured that all her explanations were both clear for a kabuki "beginner", and in-depth enough to be interesting for someone with some background knowledge. Kazui-San purchased us the most amazing tickets: sixth row, immediately next to the hanamichi runway. I really couldn't have hoped for better! She really went above and beyond to ensure that my father and I had a fabulous time at the kabuki. I'll certainly be booking another tour next time I'm in Tokyo!

From buying our tickets to putting us in our seats, this Kabuki "tour" is terrific!. Kazui met us at our hotel and took us to the Kabuki Theatre by taxi. We went to a tea salon where we enjoyed tea and a sweet while Kazui explained the layout of the theatre, talked about the actors, the meaning of certain sounds and actions and she gave us a synopsis of the two plays for which she bought us tickets (with our input as to cost and section desired). After tea we visited a small museum dealing with Kabuki theatre, then Kazui helped us purchase bento boxes to eat during intermission, just like most of the Japanese audience! Lastly, Kazui took us to our seats in the theatre and showed us how to use the translator, which was great!We enjoyed the Kabuki plays very much, however, the theatre was very hot in the first balcony. Kazui's lecture was very helpful and we noticed more because of her explanations. The acting, music, sets and costumes were wonderful! Kazui truly enhanced our enjoyment and the cost was worth it for what probably was a once-in-a-lifetime experience. Attending Kabuki theatre after learning about it from Kazui was one of the highlights of our three week trip to Japan!

Kabuki - the highlight of our trip to Tokyo Japan. Kabuki performances at the renovated and 2013 reopened Kabuki-za theatre in Chuo Tokyo are usually from the 2.nd to the 26th of the month. One can look up the dates, times and titles of performances for the current month and the next two coming months on the online Tokyo Kabuki guide. As first timers we really appreciate Kazui Yabe, a licensed Kabuki guide – interpreter, who made our Kabuki-experience a memorable one. My husband and I were in Tokyo for a week with May 2, 2016 being our last day. One month before we left for Tokyo I contacted Kazui and ordered the Kabuki tickets for May 2, 2016. This gave her enough lead time to buy the tickets at the presale, which for May 2, 2016 performance occurred in second week of April 2016. Using email Kazui edxplained all the things I need to know to see the performance. The audience sits in first, second and third floor. The most expensive seats are the box seats on left and right of the first floor. Actors enter and exit the stage via a long, raised walkway on the left of the first floor seating area. This walkway, called Hanamichi, divides the first floor into one small and one larger areas of seating. Since the actors mostly face the larger seating area, I like to be seated in the larger seating area in order to see the primordial facial expressions of the actors. During the intermissions people opened their bento boxes to have their dinner. You can buy the bento boxes from one of the restaurants in Kabuki-za or from outside stores. We opted to have dinner in a restaurant after the performance. The audience was dressed nicely. Many women as well as men came in elegant Japanese kimonos. The Kabuki show on 5/2/2016 was exceptional because of the formal introduction of a two year old Kabuki actor by his father and grandfather, two established famed Kabuki players. It was a sold out performance. Kazui herself attended the same evening performance as us but sat at a different location than us. During the intermission though she came to check on us, to see that everything is OK. Kazui Yabe is a very dedicated tour leader.Excluding three intermissions, the Kabuki performance lasted about 2hrs 50 minutes. After each act is an intermission for refreshment with the three intermissions totaling about 70 minutes altogether. Kazui’ synopsis and the English subtitle made it easy for us to follow the play. It was a most brilliant show of unique music, acting, dancing, limited but clever stage technique, all the while with outlandish painted faces and costumes. The four acts were first performed in year 2016, 1860, 1808 and 1867, in that order. The most riveting was the last act about how one of two female dancers was revealed to be a man. Both ‘female dancers’ were performed by two famous male Kabuki actors. Their sinuous and graceful movement were a delight to watch. The highlight of our 7 day trip to Tokyo was indeed the Kabuki performance. Thank you Kazui for being our excellent Kabuki private guide!

Kabuki matinee . Yabi came up on her bicycle and met me at lawsens and tea talk then all set for 5 hours of kabuki ! What a fantastic story, venue, costumes, history. English transltor sen yen a must. Thank you! 5th floor after i would have never found secret garden.

Detailed and very useful. Kazui-san was wonderful at sourcing tickets for the Kabuki for my friend and I and for giving a detailed yet concise introduction before the performance over tea and sweets. Her handouts are thoughtfully compiled and very useful. She was also kind enough to loan us binoculars and check in with us in the intervals! I would recommend booking a talk with Kazui-san if you are going to see Kabuki!

Very passionate and knowledgeable . Kazui is a warm friendly person. She is knowledgeable and extremely organised and efficient. She gave a thorough introduction to Kabuki which made the performance a hugely more meaningful experience. We were a little daunted by the length of the performance (4 hours+) but found that it was so gripping and fascinating that we didn't notice the time at all. The tea is delicious as is the venue Kazui does her introductory talk in. A bamboo tea salon high up next to a beautiful roof garden. I would highly recommend Kazui's private tour if you are going to be coming to see Kabuki for the first time. She recommended we get the English subtitles for 1000 yen. It is definitely worth the money. Thank you Kazui and all the best for your future talks. Overall it was your passion and detailed knowledge that make our experience so fantastic.Alex.

Made all the difference to appreciating the performance. Kazui's introduction (over delicious tea and ice cream) was so helpful in appreciating the depth and detail of a Kabuki perfomance. She also organised my ticket, helped me buy a bento box for lunch and provided lots of tips to help navigate the theatre and the experience. And the performance itself was wonderful - so beautiful - you can see why there are 'national treasures' among the actors.

A Necessary Tour to Help Understand Kabuki. We knew we wanted to go to a show at a Kabuki Theater but thought we would be intimidated by the show and by the process. We also knew we did not have time to watch the entire matinee or evening performance. That is why Kazui was so wonderful for us. She came well prepared with helpful information and answered all of our questions. She prepared us for the wait to get tickets for the first and second act. Her suggestion to buy a Bento Box to eat between acts was a great idea. Although we doubt we will have the opportunity to see a Kabuki show again, nor would we want to, we are so glad that we saw this show and had the pre-show guidance of Kazui. We were only with Kazui a little more than an hour but it made the following three hours enjoyable.

Guided Tour of Dance, Comedy, and Nastiness. Our family, including two teenagers were so chuffed with our Kabuki Day (7 hours from start of Kazui's talk to exiting Kabuki Theatre), that we looked to see if we could find Kabuki in Kyoto, the next stop on our Japan Tour! Kazui was punctual, responsive to emails, pleasant and informative.....and passionate about her love - Kabuki! Her information was ideal, not too detailed, for a first-time exposure, but it is clear she could talk for days about Kabuki details and history. The Museum Tour is a must, and do listen to her tips! We recommend one tablet guide per person so you can stick it into the chair in front of you and point it so you see it correctly. Do splurge if you can afford it to get close, ground-level seats for a once-in-a-lifetime theatre experience. Do buy a Bento box and fishcake to eat in your seat. You'll be amazed how tidy the audience is when you leave......almost as clean as before the show! Kabuki is amazing. If you love Opera or Theatre you must not miss it. Our teenagers are allergic to Opera but both loved Kabuki. And this tour is like the cherry on the cake for those who want to understand more of what is going on. Many thanks Kazui, please keep sharing your love!

Interesting and Informative Intro to Kabuki. Kazui gave us a wonderful introduction to our first Kabuki experience. It is such a special tradition in Japan and not to be missed as part of an overall visit, if possible. We enjoyed the performances tremendously and her summaries and orientation beforehand helped us understand even better. She even followed up with pictures of our tour and the performers we saw, which was great, since you can't take photos of the performances. She helped us secure the translation machine (highly recommended) and in so many other ways. One word of caution: if you order the bento box for the break, make sure you are hungry. Kazui will have already introduced you to some most interesting sweets and tea before the performance! Thank you again, Kazui!

A most if you love to look other kind of arts. For me and my couple it was the best way of conclude our trip to Japan and i can assure that if you love arts and specially the theathre, the Kabuki experience will change the way of seeing it. But, as a totally different kind of theatre (in comparison with the western style), you need a guidance to comprehend the basics. Because of that, the guide provided by Mrs. Kazui its essential. Besides, she´ll make the moment illustrative and enjoyable.

Excellent Experience. My friends and myself were in Tokyo over the new year and wanted to catch a Kabuki play. Not only did Kazui provide amazing assistance with seat selection and acquiring the tickets, she also provided an excellent introduction to Kabuki which allowed us to appreciate Japanese theater. Would highly recommend anyone travelling to Tokyo (with a whole afternoon / evening to spare) to take this tour!

Fun, Informative Private Kabuki Tour. This past May and June I took a two week trip to Japan. I have always wanted to see a traditional Kabuki performance in Japan, and so I researched performances and tour guides. I accidentally landed on Kazui Yabe's information while doing a Google search, and contacted her. She provided me with excellent information and arranged everything beautifully for a reasonable price. She purchased the tickets, emailed me excellent and detailed English summaries of the Kabuki plays I was to attend, described in great detail where I was sitting, emailed me the theater floor plan and photos of the seating arrangement, and arranged a brief meeting where we would have a pre-performance meeting of tea, green-tea ice cream (delicious!) and she lectured on Kabuki. Her background information was fantastic, and very good. Without her assistance I would not have understood nor would I have appreciate the performance as much as I did. After her lecture, she walked me to the Kabuki-Za Theater, graciously took pictures of me in front of the theater, toured me around the theater, helped me purchase a yummy bento box, and gave me last minute information about the production! I loved the performance(s) and even though I do not speak Japanese, my love of music and theater makes me try to attend some kind of live performance wherever I travel in the world. Her English summaries and lectures made it unnecessary for me to know Japanese -- I understood everything and enjoyed the performance a great deal. I highly recommend trying to see Kabuki when you are in Japan, and if you are in Tokyo, definitely contact Kazui Yabe!

Fabulous introduction to Kabuki. My husband and I visited Japan for the first time in early October 2015. We wanted to attend a Kabuki performance but were unsure about how to go about it. I read about Kazui Yabe's tours on another website and emailed an inquiry to her. I received a prompt response with thoughtful answers to all my questions. She offered to purchase tickets for us (in the section we desired), meet us at the theater for tea, sweets and a pre-performance private lecture before the show. I was pleasantly surprised on all counts. She loves Kabuki, is extremely knowledgable and does a very professional job of explaining what we would see, complete with illustrations. Her presentation provided us exactly the right amount of information to thoroughly enjoy the two pieces we saw. We thought we might be overwhelmed by this new-to-us form of theater but with the background we received we found we loved every minute - even though the performances ran four hours, with intermission. We highly recommend this tour.

Kabuki nights!. I was fortunate enough to travel to Japan two years in a row (2014 and 2015) and both times I had the pleasure of taking the Kabuki tour with Kazui-san. What a wonderful and interesting experience it has been!!! Besides the fact that she is extremely knowledgeable about Kabuki in particular and all other Japanese traditional performing arts, Kazui-san is totally nice and open to illustrate to foreigners the Japanese way of life. Both times at the Kabuki-za have been mesmerizing, as the visual impact of the plays is fantastic – and even if I do not understand the language I was able to follow the storyline thanks to the lecture previous to the show and have a wonderful time! This last May, since we knew each other already, we also enjoyed some sort “extra-curricular” activities, so we went to have dinner at a wonderful izakaya and also to a marvelous sushi bar, and she was extremely helpful to explain all the different ingredients and dishes that we were eating.I totally recommend her tour, also because you can really feel how dedicated and passionate about the Kabuki theater she is.Hopefully I can go back to Tokyo sometimes soon and enjoy another spectacular Kabuki night!

Not to Be missed!! . One of the best experiences ever! The booking was so smooth. Ms. Kazui arranged everything and emailed us with all the details beforehand. On the day of the show, we sat on a beautiful tea shop, indulged on delicious matcha desserts and had a very interesting lecture about the show. Ms. Kazui was so thorough and sweet. She did not even forget my husband's birthday and got him the sweetest gift. As for the show, it was history coming to life✨ ❤️ Love you Kazui all the way from Dubai! Anata wa Iciban ❤️

Kabukitastic. Met Kazui for the pre lecture and tea. It made the performance a lot more sense and much more real . I loved everything about the day . Absolutely amazing and I would certainly do it all again in 2017 when I plan to return to Japan . Thank you again for all your help Kazui .

Wonderful Kabuki Experience. I had engaged with Ms Kazui twice for both of my Japan trips. She is really nice and helpful. She speaks fluent English as well. She helped us to buy tickets, explain to us the Kabuki culture and show us around the Kabuki Theater in Ginza. She will explain to us the culture while having traditional Japanese sweets and matcha. I enjoyed her private Kabuki tour very much and will always engage her whenever I go to Tokyo. She makes me feel how beautiful Kabuki is as an art performance.

Perfect Kabuki Tour!. We had a great day at the Kabuki.... There's a lot going on with plenty of symbolism, history and protocol. Thanks to Kazui-san's tour we got a lot of insights into Kabuki which made it a very enjoyable experience. Without the tour we would've been completely lost!

Great experience and wonderful guide.. I am a clown/physical performer in Los Angeles, and I am a big fan of all forms of physical theatre, especially when rooted in rich traditions like Kabuki. When I went to Japan I knew I would see a Kabuki show, but taking this tour made the experience. I was so much better able to understand and appreciate the experience with the tour. Also, the guide is kind and convivial and truly an enthusiastic aficionado of the art form. I wouldn't have had the same experience without her.

An Excellent Introduction to Kabuki. The guide purchased Kabuki tickets for us, met us before the performances, took us to a tea shop and discussed Kabuki with us, and then walked us to the theatre. After hearing the guide’s insightful talk, we were surprised by how much we enjoyed the performances. I’d expected to have a much cooler response to an alien art form, and so many reports we read online, etc., seemed to suggest that while interesting, this form of theatre was slow-moving and boring to Western eyes and ears. But we weren’t bored at all. It was like watching Western opera and dance both at the same time. We found the differences between the three plays we saw fascinating: the first a melodramatic soap opera, the second an amusing comedy of errors, the third a stately dance ritual. And yet all were clearly Kabuki, all shared similar uses of stage conventions, makeup, etc. It reminded me of the Japanese meals we ate while we were there—a little of this and a little of that, tastefully arranged and all forming a harmonious whole. We were intrigued by the combinations of sights and sounds and movements—and especially perplexed and intrigued by the switches between the actors and the narrator in describing the feelings and responses of the same character. We were sometimes bewildered by the characters’ assumptions about the proper way to behave to one’s master or servants and such, and intrigued to be bewildered in that way. It implied a whole range of cultural assumptions previously unknown to us, and gave us new ways of thinking about the contemporary Japan outside the Kabuki theatre. While renting the English translation guide was a big help, I’m quite sure that it was less so than all the information the guide provided us with before we arrived at the theatre. We were especially intrigued to learn about the relationships among the Kabuki actors. All in all, the whole experience made for an excellent and worthwhile day.

A must-do tour for Kabuki. My partner and I travelled to Japan and wanted to see a Kabuki show - this turned out to be one of the best experiences we had in Japan, we were overwhelmed ! Kazui's lecture and the show were completely beyond our expectations, we also had great seats and it's definitely a tour we would recommend to anybody visiting Japan and wanting to know more about its culture. Fantastic!

KABUKI? A MUST-DO!!!!!. I was travelling to Japan this summer, and among all other sites (which are too many to cover them in just 3 week, but ok...) we decided to see a kabuki performance, too. I chose a private tour guide, Mrs. Kazui Yabe. I just want to tell that she's a great expert and since this is quite a different type of theatre that we are used to joining her tour is essencial for understanding and enjoying the performance in full. So, if anyone is planning a visit to Tokyo, don't miss the kabuki performance and Kazui's explainations. You won't regret it.

Absolutely essential tour!. Kabuki is one of Japan's traditional performing arts, combining traditional stories, dance, intricate makeup, and exaggerated performances. As a result, it is nearly impossible to understand without explanation. Kazui Yabe is an expert on kabuki; her pre-performance lectures--typically over local sweets and tea--provide important context that is essential in order to understand the performance. Her explanation focuses specifically on the performance about to be viewed, but also more generally on the history of kabuki, the kabuki stage, the lineage of kabuki actors, and the meaning behind the intricate makeup designs. I have attended four of her kabuki lectures, and have learned something each time. If you are planning to see a kabuki performance, I very strongly encourage you to retain Kazui's guide services.

Excellent!. This is the third time we have used this service when taking small groups to Kabuki in Tokyo, and each time has been wonderful. Kazui Yabe is not only a Kabuki expert, but also an excellent communicator about the art form. In her presentations, she gives newcomers a good sense of what to look for and listen for, as well as provides helpful historical context. Her passion for Kabuki is infectious. I highly recommend this service.

Great way to see Kabuki in Tokyo!. I had wanted to see Kabuki while in Tokyo but didn't know how to go about purchasing tickets or even if I would understand what I was seeing. After searching on the internet, I found Kazui Yabe's website and after communicating with her - everything was easy. Kazui was so helpful while we were planning our trip, replying to multiple e-mails with great advice on what types of seats to purchase and with other information on what people usually do about meals while at Kabuki, etc. She purchased the tickets for us, which was an enormous help and arranged to meet us outside the theater on the day of the performance. We went to a tea salon for tea and a sweet (included in her very reasonable price) and she gave us information on Kabuki and the particular performance we were seeing. She even had handouts for us. Then we toured the little museum at the theater before the performance. During the first intermission in the performance she helped obtain a particular type of sweet that she had recommended that was sold at the theater and brought it to us after we looked a little confused about how to go about finding the vendor ourselves (which was really above and beyond what we would have expected). Kazui has a lot of enthusiasm for Kabuki and really wants to share her love of Kabuki with visitors. She made the process of seeing Kabuki very easy and really enhanced our enjoyment of it. We wouldn't have had nearly as much insight into what we were seeing had we tried to do this on our own. I highly recommend doing this tour!

Calm and Enjoyable. We went to Kanji House as part of our honeymoon. We both got our names translated into Kanji on small scrolls. Io, the lady that translated our names for us, spent a lot of time asking us questions about ourselves and each other in order to find the most fitting Kanji names. She was very polite and studious. Understanding a little about Kanji and how it works was lovely. We came out calm and happy, ready to take a walk around Asakura.

Guided Tour Service. Norie, my tour guide has a pretty extensive knowledge of Asakusa and its history. She answered all of my questions and took the time to explain them in great details. My phone stopped working, the night before I was about to leave for Tokyo. I had to asked Norie, if we can use her phone to take pictures. She gladly took the photos and emailed them to me.Great Service!

Lovely girls, authentic place and wonderful kanji names!. My girlfriend and I booked this activity in advance and had no issues in getting in touch for further info concerning transportation and the activity itself. The location was very easy to find as we were previously provided with some guidelines including photos. As soon as we arrived, we were welcomed by these lovely girls and the atmosphere was simply nice. During the activity, you are supposed to list some personality characteristics, so they can work out which is your kanji name. Personally, we found it very interesting and appreciated the fact that the decision is not up to just one individual. There will be a consultation in front of a proper dictionary and they will make sure you will understand it too. Well done, Kanjj House!!!! Our kanji names are living in our bedroom from now on. It is definitely recommended.

Fun tour of Asakusa!. My wife and I had a very nice afternoon with Norie exploring Asakusa and the Sensoji temple area plus we got our names written in Kanji as a souvenir after. The guided tour offered by Kanji House is a must do for anyone visiting Tokyo. Norie was very friendly and a great guide showing us not only the temple area but around as well.
Quiet time to relax and experience Kanji writing. We went there with my children 11 and 15 and had a very nice time experiencing explanations about Kanji writing.

The best souvenir you can get by far!. I'll keep it short: I bought chop sticks, sake cups, "good luck" charms, candies, toys ..... the list goes on. But your name as a kanji is the best souvenir which I could get!And it is also suited for a dear friend/your girlfriend/wife, even if she is not here. A kanji name is based on your original name, but it also incorporates various hobbies, skills and personality traits of the person. To simplyfy it: let's say you are Steven, and you like hiking (and various other hobbys/traits). The staff will look for syllables based on your name ("St-" for example) and your trait. So the first kanji of your name is "St-" with the meaning of "mountain" for example.It was easily the best experience in Tokyo! Don't miss out!PS: the staff is super friendly!

Fun and relaxing. What a pleasant way to spend a few hours in Asakusa. Minami was engaging and knowledgeable. Takumi and Masahumi were fun as they helped us come up with ideas for kanji characters that exemplified personal character traits. After creating a list, they researched and then drew beautiful kanji character names.All in all, great fun and we really enjoyed it. Thank you!!

Amazing experience!. Kanji House is nothing short of amazing. I came with 2 other friends on a Saturday with no reservation. They were cleanimg at the time and despite that, Rena & Minami graciously welcomed us in.Rena & Minami were awesome hosts. They asked us a few questions about ourselves and from there, were able to write our name with kanji letters that reflected our personalities.In the meanwhile, we had a great time discussing the (large) differences in Australian & Japanese culture. They both spoke very good English (and us very poor Japanese!) which made the experience very casual and entertaining. Rena also was kind enough to find, book and personally guide us to a Kimono dress shop nearby. The experience was so good that we contacted them and came back again to get gifts for our loved friends and family! Unfortunately I didnt get the other two peoples names that were there at the time but they were very helpful as well. We also did some origami crafts in the meantime and explained how aussies abbrev. everything.We had our names written in scrolls which was super cool. I would highly recommend anybody to come here and get their name written in kanji. Also makes for a great sentimental gift if you get them for your friends & family.Thanks again!

I wish I had more hands so i could give Kanji House 4 thumbs up!. Purchased an authentic Japanese scroll with my name in Kanji which was awesome. So awesome we came back a second time to get more as presents. I'd like to add the atmosphere was traditional and relaxing and we were able to have a few laughs and get some cultural insight into Japan. I have been learning Japanese and Menami made it easy for me to practice, with her knowledge of both Japanese and English. We finished by getting a selfie with the staff so all in all MUST VISIT. Thanks again from Australia Menami. Australia>AmericaRegards, Rob AKA Desert King

One of the highlights of my visit to Tokyo. The visit at the Kanji House was lovely. The two students Nahoko und Keira were amazing. So kind and smart and fun to talk to. It was so interesting to hear from them about the alphabets and the Japanese culture. Such a great experience to have your name written in Kanji and getting to try writing it yourself, too. I would highly recommend to visit the Kanji House.

Amazing experience!. My wife and I took a guided tour of Asakusa with Rena from Kanji house and it was an awesome experience. She was genuinely interested in conversing with us as well as telling us all about Senso-ji temple. She gave us a choice of several types of food we would like to try on our way through the area as well. We would have gladly paid for just the tour and the lovely conversation but the amazing personal touch of the calligraphy just made it so memorable. Rena sat with us personally for quite a while asking my wife and I about one another before she chose the kanji that best represented us. And of course the calligraphy was a work of art. We would recommend Kanji House to absolutely everyone visiting Tokyo! Rena was an amazing hostess and based on the reviews here I can assume everyone else at Kanji House is too! No matter your age this can't be missed. Easily one of the highlights of our trip.And if you meet Rena don't forget to ask her about the Tanuki war!

Great experience!. We had such a lovely time there! We ordered names in Kanji and calligraphy lesson, Kanji symbols were carefully chosen appropriate to our characters (we didn't know it's such a hard work like investigation), then we moved to calligraphy when we could try drawing our names and extra words by myself in traditional way (which was very pleasant experiment).Hosts were very helpful and answered many questions about Japan's tradition and history. I really recommend this way of spending some time in Japan! Worth every Yen!Many, many thanks to Nahoko and Keita!

What a fantastic Japanese experience. It's a way you get to experience the Japanese culture Our hosts were fantastic,they explain every detail of having your name written in kanji Can recommend this activity to everyone going to Asakusa

Great treat for the kids. We had a great experience at Kanji House with our small children. First, they had to introduce themselves to our hosts so they can choose the appropriate Kanji for their names. Then we chose the scroll for the kanji name and watched as our host wrote the calligraphy for us. Then, we were able to practice some writing ourselves ! What a treat and the kids loved it ! We also received some Japanese traditional candies to take home! You must visit Kanji house if you are in Asakusa with small children !

Great way to enjoy Asakusa!. I came across Kanji House while searching for things to do in Asakusa. I saw they provided a great package where we were able to wear kimonos while being shown around Asakusa and booked with them via their website. They were very prompted with a response. I had a great time and so did my mum! I was also surprised when they also taught us how to make a origami crane and also wrote our names in kanji using information they gathered during the tour! Amazing! Thanks Asami and Nahoko!

A Local Perspective of Asakusa!. We stumbled across Kanji House via Trip Advisor reviews, and this experience far surpassed our expectations. We signed up for the guided tour (which was a private tour and included the calligraphy) and origami. Rena and Seiko were our tour guides for the afternoon, and they were so helpful. Their English is very good and their knowledge of the neighborhood is great. When touring around, we mentioned the few souvenirs we still wanted to buy. They took us to some local shops and helped us purchase our items at great prices. Even though these detours made our tour longer than planned for, Rena and Seiko were very friendly and accommodating. Upon returning to Kanji House they explained the selected letters/symbols that make up the Kanji spelling of our names and taught us how to make origami animals. As we ended our afternoon, Seiko walked us to get the local Asakusa specialty - melon bread - before walking us to the train station. I would highly recommend Kanji House for anyone looking for a unique Tokyo experience with highly attentive tour guides!

Amazing place!!. Had such an amazing time. Nohoko and Kazuki really took the time to get to know us so that our Kanji really represented who we are as people. The booking process is really simple, just send an email and they reply very promptly. I highly recommend anyone going to Japan to visit Kanji House. Remember the honesty rule Kazuki

Great experience in Asakusa!. We had a lovely time with Kazuki and Asami at Kanji House. We felt welcomed from the moment we arrived. It was good to chat to Kazuki as we learned about about kanji and the Japanese culture. The kanji letters Kazuki selected for our names were very thoughtful and most appreciated. While we waited, we were offered Japanese sweets and Asami showed us how to make an origami kimono! I wish I could remember all the instructions! Asami then wrote our kanji names very carefully in calligraphy which was interesting to watch. Kazuki explained to each of us why he had selected the particular kanji letters for our names which was a lovely personal touch. It was definitely a highlight of our trip to Tokyo because of the warm and friendly way in which Kazuki and Asami interacted with the whole family, the opportunity to learn about Japanese culture and the traditional and peaceful setting in Asakusa. I would recommend it as something a little different and very worthwhile to do while in Tokyo that you will remember for years to come.
A Must Do!. We got the Calligraphy class and the tour of Asakusa. We had a great time, got excellent souvenirs and a splendid tour of the area! Thank you Minami, Eri and Asami! :D

Amazing experience! Wonderful cultural exchange!. I went to the Kanji House on the 17th of March, and it was a wonderful experience! I am very much happy to have gone here. Saiko and Asami are extremely friendly, kind, and welcoming. Even if I went alone, they made me feel "at home," and there was never a dull moment during my visit. They showed me around Asakusa area in Kimono, they gave me more information about the area, as well as information about the Japanese culture. I also got my Kanji name. The calligraphy itself is art at its finest! It is most definitely the best and the most unique souvenir anyone could ever have while in Japan. To foster a lovely cultural exchange, I translated their names to Baybayin calligraphy. This is a unique experience, and I am highly recommending this to anyone who plans to wander around Asakusa area :)

Fantastic experience with lovely people. My family and I went to the Kanji house on Saturday 20th Feb and had a lovely time with the ladies there. They were friendly and informative and were very hospitable. I highly recommend going for a visit if you are staying in Tokyo. Great city great people great experience

Amazing Opportunity & Kindness. This experience at Kanji-House was one of the highlights of our visit to Tokyo! And have definitely received the best souviener we could ask for. Its a really thoughtful, personal experience and it couldn't have been more welcoming by Nahoko & Eri. We are so happy to have met these individuals who added culture and further knowledge into our visit. Definitely recommend coming here, our friends were gutted we lost them in Asakusa as they too would have loved the experience, so stick together and take a wander to the Kanji-House, its definitely worth while :)

Wonderful souvenir from an enjoyable experience. Stumbled upon the girls by accident nearby and thought why not. Definitely my highlight of the Asakusa area. Spent an hour or so talking and everything from uni to culture while relaxing. Certainly going to recommend this to everyone!

Great memory and perfect souvenir. It was an excellent experience for me. Both of them were so kind and funny. First they welcomed us very warm. Naoki asked me and my girlfriend many questions about my personality to decide a suitable Kanji for me. While he was searching from kanji dictionary, we talked about many things and they taught me how to do my first Origami. After they decided my Kanji, they wrote my kanji with a perfect art. I'm really glad to visit there and meet them. I want to go there again when I visit Japan again.

Amazing kindness and care. To book an appointment you should send an e-mail! Answers are fast!So, the writing ceremony is really, really lovely. Mieko were the perfect hostess and showed us around and told us about the traditional life of the Japanese. For the writing of the names she asked us about our interests and then asked the other to tell her about your good traits. She is a good listener and a great observer. She takes great care in her work and it was wonderful to hear her explain about the kanji she chose at the end. The handiworks was lovely and we got the pieces framed. Really loved this personal gift!Cannot recommended this enough!

Really fun and educational experience!. Really happy we visited the Kanji House, and the host, Meiko, was really warm and welcoming! They responded super quick on email and were very helpful in finding a time that worked for us. Creating the Kanji and talking about different traditional Japanese items took about 1 hour and we enjoyed every minute of it. The host was really sweet, kind and helpful. Would easily recommend this to anyone!

Great fun and fantastic souvenir. Very friendly and welcoming. Explaining why they chose each kanji character and how it relates to our personalities was a big plus. A great souvenir to take home for a cheap price.

Wonderful experience . This was a highlight of my whole trip to Japan. The staff were so kind and really took the time to figure out the best Kanji characters to represent my personality and life experience. And the end product was a beautiful reminder to take home. Highly recommended!

Can't rate high enough. A massive highlight of my trip to Japan was visiting the Kanji House, we were welcomed so warmly by them after they opened up specifically for us on a day they would normally be shut over the holidays and we were made to feel so welcome and appreciated. I can't thank them enough for such a brilliant time and their patience with us for explaining the meaning behind the Kanji used for our names and the professional calligrapher who wrote them out for us! If you are interested in learning a little about Kanji and how your name can be interpreted into the language or just seeing something off the well beaten tourist track in the area then this place is highly recommended!

Amazing experience with Japanese traditional clothes and products!. There were many amazing experiences with kind staffs in cozy space.You can experience...- Wearing Japanese traditional clothes "Kimono"Women can wear beautiful color Kimono and men can wear Samurai style Kimono. There are Kimono dressers to support us.- Sightseeing with a tour guide in AsakusaA tour guide explains about Asakusa history in English.- Writing Kanji characters as your nameAfter some communications, a staff who is good at Japanese writing chooses Kanji characters for you.
A must do in Tokyo!!!. Easygoing and very kind people. They're going to ask some question about yourself and then they'll write your name in kanji based on your answers. Just amazing!!!

Fantastic experience, great gift to take home.. We absolutly loved Kanji House! It was a fantastic experience and very cheap. The ladies were lovely and very cute in their kimono's. They were so helpful and taught us about japanese tradition for New Years Eve. Then we got to take home our personalised names which is a great momento from our time in Japan. It is well worth the trip to Asakusa.

"Big Magic" moment. This was the most unexpected interaction in my week long stay in Tokyo. Out of the blue, it became a beautiful memory for myself and an amazing gift to my wife. Both Rena and her partner were respectful, patient and extremely loveable. Don't skip this truly "Big Magic" moment, you will love it !!
Kanji Doho. What a great experience, and so cheap! 100% must do for an unforgettable memory preserved on a personalized souvenir. A little hard to find but very central, near Asakusa Station.

A unique Japanese cultural experience. Because my adult daughter and son were visiting Japan for the first time, I really wanted an opportunity for them learn something about Japanese culture by meeting/interacting with Japanese people, in addition to visiting tourist and shopping sites. After reading about Kanji House on TripAdvisor, I emailed Rena Makita and we made plans to visit Kanji House a Friday morning after seeing the Sensoji temple. We were greeted at Kanji House by Asami-san, who interviewed all of us to learn more about my daughter and son as people. Based on the information that she gathered, Asami-san came up with with the Kanji characters for their names, and we were surprised how perceptive Asami-san was in selecting the specific characters with their meaning.We had a lot of places to visit that day because we were in Tokyo for only two days, so our visit was short, but I will say without hesitation that the visit to Kanji House was an absolute must! This isn't a touristy site where everything is "packaged" Disneyland style, but a real opportunity to interact with Japanese people and experience their culture.If there's one thing I would suggest to the young ladies at Kanji House: the time that you spend and the unique experience you offer is worth more than 1000 yen - I think most tourists would be happy to contribute 1500 yen/name to Kanji House.

One of my best memories of Japan.. When I was first approached by Rena at the entrance to Sensō-ji Temple, I wasn't sure what was happening. Immaculately dressed in a traditional komono, she started to explain the experience available to me at Kanji House. At first I was unsure being wary of the potential of a tourist trap but remembered I was in Japan where this is unlikely to occur. Rena explained that Kanji House was run by students and an opportunity to have my name written in Kanji as a momento. I enquired about the cost and was told it was up to Y2000 (USD17/AUD22) but other options were available too.While we took the 5 minute walk to Kanji House we chatted about my travels and Rena's studies.The steep stairs of Kanji House opened to a room where I met Yui. After being served with green tea, Yui asked questions about my name, my personality and thoughts on different topics. After some reflection Rena dipped her brush into the ink and painted three Kanji characters onto a sheet of beautiful rice paper.Yui then explained the meaning of each character and how it related to the pronunciation of my name and my personality traits.Unable to select a frame due to baggage restrictions, I chose a Sumo motif from a selection of Japanese cotton sheets and this was folded into a frame for me by Rena.Overall, it was one of my best memories from Japan and in the end the only souvenir I brought home with me.If you would like to experience some real and traditional sharing of Japanese culture I would highly recommend Kanji House to you.I hear that the venture is struggling to stay open, so please support Kanji House and experience one of your best memories of Japan.Thank you Rena and Yui!

Very enjoyable and personal experience. The neighborhood is fun, tons of little shops. Also, you might already be nearby because you were visiting Senso-Ji Temple. The girls at Kanji took their time in getting to know us with characteristics and descriptors, and then one of them used the extensive kanji dictionary to find characters to fit us specifically and personally. We also had a fun time creating an origami swan while we waited. Our kanji name frames now sit on our mantle at home in our living room!

Surprise visit to Kanji House, fantastic experience . We were approached in the street by a young lady in a kimono who asked whether we wanted our names written in kanji calligraphy for free. We were a little unsure at first as we were led down a few streets towards the building - back home in England following strangers into a building is not something you do! However we were pleasantly relieved when we saw the sign for Kanji House and entered the building. Asami and Nozomi were incredibly nice and friendly and spent lots of time learning about us, deciding the kanji for or names and teaching us about kanji, and also showing us some origami and other Japanese things. We really enjoyed our visit to Kanji House and it was not something we were expecting to do at all. If you do get the chance to visit, you really must! Of course you can pay for frames for your kanji names too which we happily did. The great thing is you are able to take home both a physical souvenir and a great experience. Thank you Asami-san and Nozomi-san, it was great to meet you and best wishes for Kanji House!Daniel and George

Surprisingly good. We didn't realize that this sort of thing existed. We were approached in the street and asked if we wanted some personlized Kanji. I thougt in the back ofmy mind that this was some sort of crazy trap as we went up into their building.Plot twist, they were actually very sweet and informative and the Kanji was beautiful.Definitely going back next time if I travel with others.Price wise it was stated at 1,000 yen for a piece of Kanji, but we received it for free because they found us in the street. You can also buy frames from them from around 2,000 yen.There's other things in the shop to purchase as well such as ornaments.If you plan on checking out the sky tree, take a detour through the markets around Kanji house and stop by on your way through. You won't regret it.

Genuine and enjoyable Japanese experience. I loved this place, it was one of my favourite things I did in Tokyo. I heard about this from a fellow traveller who'd had a nice time, so went off in search of it. The girls are really friendly, hard working and they certainly know their craft. After a chat with one of the girls, she came up with two Kanji characters that spelled my name and had a symbolism that she felt resonated with my character. Then, while she and I had a chat over some tea, another calligraphy student painted it out for me to keep. A really special little keepsake from my time in Japan - make sure you go to Kanji House!

Sometimes you need to letting go. I usually don't say yes when people approach me in the street to try to sell me something or talk about their shop.But that was my last day in Japan and I decide to letting go. Sometimes it's good to don't plan everything and let the things happen to you.I am glad to have followed Rena to her Kanji house. I spent a good time over there talking about Japan and different culture. the shop is warmly and the people are very nice. I wish you the best in your future projects.Regards.

Delightful experience!. The girls at the shop were super friendly. They taught us how to make an origami frog while we waited for our names to be translated into Kanji. The final result was a work of art, truly beautiful. We will cherish this memory.
Kanji House review. My Sister and I loved the kanji house! Thanks to Nozomi and Asami for there amazing service. Highly recommend to any traveller around Tokyo

Very nice experience, very friendly ladys. Kanji House was a great experience, the friendly ladys take much time to get you to know, you can have a cup of tea and very much fun together. My written Kanji name hangs framed in my room back home and is a great memory to the amazing time in Tokyo with my new friends. When you are at kaminari you should definately stop by. In the end it's super cheep (too cheep for the great experience i think).I hope their store will stay there for a long time.Thank you if you read this.

A must do!. My wife and I stopped by the Kanji House after hearing about it on TripAdvisor. We were met by Asami who was extremely friendly and took her time in getting to know us and creating a Kanji based on our name and personality. This was truly a one of a kind experience, and a keepsake that we'll have forever!

Pleasant and memorable experience!. I absolutely recommend this place! As I was wondering and exploring my way through the market lanes of Asakusa, I was lucky enough to be approached by a lovely lady by the name Yui. She showed me the way to Kanji House where I was greeted by two more ladies. These ladies not only amazingly talented but they were wonderful and so sweet! The house was very beautifully styled, very traditional and was infused by a incredibly nice scented aroma. They made my day by creating a beautiful creation of my name that depicts my personality in Kanji. I bought a gorgeous frame to match the writing. The Kanji House truly made my visit in Japan even better!

An amazing experience for foreigners who want to take a look into Japanese culture and writing.. I found this place while browsing through TripAdvisor on a rainy Monday morning and it seemed like something that I would really like to try out.The place was easy to reach using the public transport and it is also very close to the temple in Asakusa.I was invited inside and made to feel welcome whle they asked me a few questions about myself in order to write my name in Kanji characters. I also took a look around the house which had several traditional Japanese souvenirs and also some Japanese games.They also took to time to explain some things to be about Japanese writing and how every character in a name has its own meaning, so names which sound the same actually have different interpretations.You have the choice to take your name in Japanese in either a frame or a local handkerchief which can be used in various ways, and the price for this is reasonable.All in all this is a great experience for anyone visiting Tokyo, and one of my personal highlights!

Excellent!. So happy we (Genbukan Tenzan dojo, Kamayari dojo, Ryusui dojo) could experience this great way to learn more about traditional Japanese culture.Some of us have been many times to Asakusa but this time was the best.Thank you very much Kanji House people.All the best from Belgium.

Memorable Chance Encounter. My husband and I visited Japan in October 2015 for our 35th Anniversary and while wondering the streets of Asakusa we were approached by a beautiful, soft spoken Japanese girl dressed in a Kimono asking us if we wanted to visit her studio to have our names written in Kanji. My husband and I were hesitant as that is exactly what tourists are told not to do, do not follow a stranger, but for some reason we followed her and was so happy we did.We entered a beautiful Japanese room with Tatami mats and were greeted by another Japanese gentle beauty with two cups of green tea. We had great conversation while our names were carefully painted in Kanji with Indian Ink on parchment paper. We had planned to buy a Japanese souvenir however once we saw these depictions of our names and personalities in Kanji buying any other souvenir no longer seemed meaningful.It is such a worthwhile experience, we paid CDN$20 for each frame but it was worth every penny, spending $100 on another souvenir would not have been as meaningful.It is uncharacteristic for us to have followed a stranger as a tourist but it was the best decision we made, we not only had an authentic Japanese experience we met two lovely Japanese flowers and walked away with a lasting memory.So if you are in Asakusa please be sure to check out the Kanji House it will be an experience that money cannot buy.
Awesome!. Thank you Asami and Nahoko! It was an awesome experience and a great souvenir. So glad we said yes on the street, it's one of those experiences that make the trip extra special!

Just do this!. I hesitated like a fool when I met these nice guys on the street offering to write our names in Kanji for free (may be promotional, we left a small donation anyway because it was too awesome not to). I was like "20 minutes to write my name?!? so long?". Then luckily I thought "maaaaan, why not? this stuff I can't usually find on every street anyway..." and just did it. Definitely one of the more interesting things I have done in Japan, or ever traveling for that matter, and these guys were super nice, and I don't wanna give you any spoilers but the process they go through was awesome to the core. Loved the idea.

Welcoming, hospitable experience. We were also picked up off the street by Asami. Didn't know what to expect but we're more than pleasantly surprised by the hospitality. Nahoko took her time to interview us. And while she was constructing our Kanji names Asami showed us how to make some Origami. Eventually Asami wrote down our names in Kanji. I had my wife's name done and my own name. If I ever come back to Tokio I will have my children's names done.Thank you again Asami and Nahoko for a lovely experience.

Lovely experience . I'm so thankful that we ran into Rena while wandering around Asakusa. Her and her coworker are the sweetest girls, and you won't regret paying them a visit. It was such a sweet, simple, and easy cultural exchange - free of charge! Although, by the end of the visit I wanted to buy something just as a small way of saying "thank you" - even though I never felt in the least bit obligated to do so. We shared things about our selves and about our cultures, and walked away with some of my favorite souvenirs as well as memories of my stay in Tokyo.Thanks again, Girls!!!

Awesome people. Super nice people offer writing your name in Kanji after matching it with your personality. You also have the option to frame, with a bit extra money. That was awesome cultural experience to me. I love those people. Highly recommending this place!! It's the highlight of my stay in Tokyo so far!

Great Experience and Fantastic Souvenir. Our trip started a little different from most. My friends and I went to Asakusa after being told by a few locals in other area's that it is a great place to visit and we must go there. So we decided one morning to jump on the metro and head straight there. Only once we got off the train and up to the main streets of Asakusa did we realise that we never actually asked anyone what to do in Asakusa. Whilst walking through the streets, most likely looking like the lost tourists that we were, we were approached by Rena and Yui who asked if we were interested in having our names wrote in Kanji and that they were students at Tokyo University. After chatting for a little bit my friends and I decided to to go with them to there shop to have our names created in Kanji.The experience itself is free and they give you your name in Kanji on a piece of paper but if you want your new Kanji name put into a frame you will have to buy the frame which is reasonably priced which we did as it protects this souvenir and looks rather smart.Rena and Yui were extremely kind and polite and even showed us around their shop which is set up like a traditional Japanese home. I even beat my friends at the toy game of getting the ball in the cup.I would strongly suggest that people visit Kanji House as it is a fantastic experience with great people and you get a meaningful souvenir out of it.

An amazing cultural experience. My story starts out almost the same as all the others here. While visiting the area with my friends around Senso ji shrine in Asakusa I was approached by Rena san and one other girl in a traditional kimono. They explained who they were and what they were doing. After some hesitation on my part, because my friends and I were on a time shedule, I called my friends and we decided to go for it. They took us to their charming little shop decorated in Japanese style. There they took their time getting to know us so they could write our kanji. One tip, if you're practising a Japanese martial art you can ask them to write your dojo name in kanji instead of your name.They also took their time for getting some nice group pictures.Also they offer to write your kanji for free, you only have to pay for a frame or a wrapping if you want it. I'll advice to take at least the frame because the time spent with these gentle people is priceless. This was one of my best experiences while visiting Japan and I highly recommend looking them up.
Super fun. I didn't plan to go here, but was rather picked up from the street. And I'm glad that I said yes because it was fun and I enjoyed it! :)

an unexpected and pleasant adventure on our day out in asakusa. My teenage son & I were approached by the kanji house girls offering to write our names in kanji. We were taken back to their shop and treated like royalty. They gave us lots of information and were able to communicate well in English. They had some lovely products for sale at their shop. Produced beautifully calligraphy kanji for both my son & I. We intend to get them framed.I recommend seeking out kanji house it is an hour well spent and relaxing in the hubbub of tourist Tokyo.

An Unexpected Adventure. I have lived in Japan for a year and never had any chance (believe me!) to witness traditional culture of Japan. But since my family is visiting I had to take them around I chose to go the ancient gem the Sensoji Temple. On my way I bumped into a immaculately dressed lady who was offering to translate our names into Japanese and I just gave it a go! And I am glad I did, she not only translated our names but also made origamis for us. The service was and courtesy very real. I highly recommend everyone to give it a go!

A very pleasant visit to Kanji House. I was wrapping up my visit to the Sensoji Shrine in Asakusa when a lady dressed in traditional Japanese kimomo invited me to their establishment called 'Kanji House'. The ladies - Nozomi and Asami - were very hospitable and friendly. They drew my Kanji name out and explained many things about the language and other aspects of Japanese culture. It was a unique experience and I enjoyed it immensely. The shop too was very traditionally designed and interesting. I left with a beautifully drawn Kanji version of my name and I bought a few pretty traditional scarves for my relatives. I highly recommend any visitor to Tokyo should check out Kanji House.Thanks to the folks at Kanji House for my Kanji name and a pleasant end to my day.

The best surprise of my two weeks trip around Japan. First let me say that why there's no waiting line to access to this little gem, is a mystery to me. 37 "excellent" rates out of 37 reviewers can't be wrong! This place excels indeed and was one of the most special moments, and no doubt the most authentic, in my two weeks trip around Japan. Do yourself a favor and do not miss the opportunity to visit them.Now, for the longer version.Keywords: magical atmosphere; pure traditional entertainment and learning; perfect example of japanese kindness and hospitality.My brother and me were on a visit to Senso-ji temple when two charming ladies (Asami and Naoko) approached us offering to write our names in Kanji in their nearby store. The idea appealed to us, so we walked there with them, just 2-3 minutes away from the temple entrance. We immediately breathed the extremely peaceful atmosphere of the place, filled by Asami and Naoko's parsimony. They brought us tea, explained a bit of Kanji writing and started to work on our names. In sum, they pass latin character names to Kanji, trying to match the symbols with personality (they asked a few questions regarding ourselves) with a full explanation of the process and the meaning of each Kanji. While Asami, with extraordinary kanji-writing skills, wrote several beautiful versions of our names (so you can chose the one you like the most), Naoko provided colorful paper sheets to teach us origami (we made a very nice crane, mine is decorating my bedroom now :-). We left the place so glad and relaxed, a need in the busy Tokyo, thinking how peaceful the last 25 minutes of our lives had been. The price? Please, pay attention to this humble reviewer, and check for yourself how low cost a genuine and unique experience can be. I guarantee it will be a highlight on your trip!
Excellent. Lovely staff, very friendly and very skilled. My name looks amazing in kanji.Yui is very good. Thank you..............
Nice to meet you!. Hello guys!This has been an excellent moment.I am very happy to bring back home, such memories.Thanks for having written my name in Kanji!See you!

Unusual but exceptional . I went to Kanji House after reading reviews on TripAdvisor. I wanted to do something different and this sounded like just that. What can I say? I really enjoyed Kanji. Where else can you sit in a lovely room and chat with a lovely Japanese women and try some games.Absolutely brilliant and if you don't want your kanji your under no obligation to buy it. But I did and only cost 1000 yen. Really recommend coming here.

My best experience in Japan!. Only few times in ones life, a real experience results better than a dream of it.That is what happend in my trip to Japan, and probably one of the best experiences in the whole journey was the visit to Kanji House. In traditional Asakusa district, two lovely and smiling ladies, dressed in beautiful Kimonos, approached me kindly and explained their newly crowdfunded business, to write your name in japanese Kanji. Beeing a japanese art lover, I accepted, curiosly, to see where this experience would take me. We walked a few blocks, and got to a traditional japanese house, where in the second floor, Norie San and Akane San had their business, beautifully decorated. We talkes a little so that they could find out a little more about me and my life, because it is not only that they will write your name translating or transcripting it into Kanji, they really fin a meaning for each Kanji, that suits a positive caracteristic of you. Then, with brush, ink and rice paper, they write you new name in Kanji, explaining why they chose each kanji (and give you a certificate of the visit and the explanation to each Kanji). Norie San and Akane San were always very friendly, smiling, and the best host there can be. I walked back to my hotel with a smile from ear o ear, and my Kanji, framed (a must!!!) under my arm. I hope everyone can enjoy this experience aswell! :) My sincerest and warmest regards and congratulations to Norie San and Akane San.

Japanese Experience. We met two girls from Kanji House in Asakusa area and they explained us what their business about.And took us to Kanji House which is real Japanese style interior and demonstrated my name in Kanji with Japanese caligraphy.While we were there, other girl showed us how to make origami.Whole experience was all free, they were so friendly and good cultual experience!

Thanks a lot!. We had a really great time at kanji house. We not only received fabulous looking calligraphies of our names, but we were also treated so kindly and got to meet Yoshino and Hiroki, two very nice university students. If you're in the area don't hesitate to stop by! You will definitly remember this experience!

Definitely worth a visit!!!!!. This cute little attraction is definitely worth a visit. After being welcomed in this cozy and neatly decorated traditional little room, the assistants will ask you to describe your character and will then, based on your personality, choose your personal Kanji characters, which will be given to you in lovely calligraphic writing as a souvenir. We experienced an extraordinarily friendly atmosphere. Go for it!

Loved the Kanji-House. It was a wonderful experience at the Kanji-House which I will not forget! We sat down in a very traditional room and talked with the friendly staff. The Kanji they created for us fit our characters very well because we had to describe ourselves and our hobbies. I recommend this place :)

Great personalized service!. Very nice girls took us into their unique old-fashioned room with tatami mats, a low table and sliding paper doors. They offered us iced tea and little sweets, and treated to a unique experience by getting our names translated into kanji, which was then beautifully penned with a brush and ink onto rice paper. Both the girls were super sweet, informative and gave us a unique view into a small part of their culture.

A fun experience and a good souvenir. Sitting down and talking with the staff at the Kanji House is an experience I'll never forget. Instead of finding out the appropriate Kanji for my name my asking dry questions, the answers came naturally as we casually chatted about our interests to each other. Before I knew it, my name was done, and it seemed to reflect me perfectly. I recommend the Kanji House to anyone who wants to gain a slighly clearer view of themselves through Kanji.

Brilliant experience!. I completely and whole-heartedly recommend this place! We met two wonderful women, Asami and Yoshino, who created a kanji name for our last (or first) name based on our personalities. Drinking green tea in a very Japanese-style living area while discussing the different kanji possibilities (good English!), it was relaxing and fun! Being very close to Sensouji Temple, it is in a great location - very easy to find. Having your name written out for you in Kanji is of course free, which if very nice as well! We bought the beautiful wraps for the sheet for 1000yen, but it is not pushed on you at all, we just thought it more than worth it.Don't miss out on this unique experience while in Tokyo! Thank you for earlier! ^-^
Really fun!. Visited this place pretty much spontaneously after leaving the Sensoji temple! It was lots of fun, and I'm so excited to have the kanji for my name, and the calligraphy is very pretty!

Truly unique. More or less secluded in a street 1 minute from Senso-ji temple, this place is truly one of a kind. Two welcoming ladies define your Kanji name, including your personality through an interview. You can then ask all kinds of questions about Japan or Tokyo. And you get a nice cup of tea.

Amazing experience. . We have visited this place by pure accident. But it was worth. Both me and my friend have our name calligrapher by one of the girls in Japanese. And it is not only direct translation but girls also take into consideration your character. And also final "version" looks perfect. Definitively place to visit while in Tokyo and also thing to have. Piotr & Slawek.

Great Memory of Tokyo. My girlfriend and I had a great time at Kanji house. This memorable authentic japanese experience was an absolute highlight during our time in Japan. Your name is translated to Japanese, also taking into consideration your hobbies and personality. Thank you so much for this great experience!
Nice to have your name in Kanji. it was very nice experience to have. your name in Kanji. Also the girls are very nice and always smiling. The shop is open between 11:00-18:00.
don't miss out on this experience!. great offer, super nice and very interresting! get your name written in Kanji - selected based on your personality & interrests.

Excellent experience. Asakusa is more beatiful because of these girls. They are so charming and marvellous. They made us have a very nice day. We had a very interesting conversation where all of us learn from each other, and lots and lots of laughs. Perfect day. Thank you girls! This is an experience that everyone visiting Japan must have. Best wishes from Celeste and her mother Alicia (We hanged our kanji names paint in our rooms. They look beatiful)
Delightful experience. It has been a wonderful experience. We have enjoyed everything in here, Kanji House.You, girls, have been amazing. We have learned a lot. Thank you.

Great experience!. We were led up some steep steps into an old, old-fashioned room with tatami mats, a low table and sliding doors.
